key_points: FBI Director Chris Wray testified before Senate, debunking the claim that January 6 Capitol rioters were 'fake Trump protesters'.
Wray stated the FBI has found no evidence that rioters were posing as Trump supporters or that Antifa was involved in the January 6 violence.
Over 260 defendants have been charged in federal court for their actions during the Capitol siege, most showing allegiance to Trump.
Wray refuted widespread voter fraud claims in the 2020 election, which have been promoted by Trump and some allies.
Despite debunking false claims, Wray did not denounce lawmakers who endorse QAnon conspiracy theories.
Senator Richard Blumenthal expressed disappointment over Wray's reluctance to condemn elected officials amplifying QAnon theories.
Wray defended FBI's sharing of the 'Norfolk memo', an intelligence report about potential threats before the Capitol attack.
The Norfolk report was shared with law enforcement including Capitol Police through email, a verbal briefing, and a law enforcement portal.
Wray admitted he did not see the Norfolk report until after January 6 and mentioned the challenge of sharing intelligence across departments.
The FBI aims to develop better sources for gaining intelligence on domestic extremists, with arrests providing valuable information.
spokespersons: Dick Durbin (Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Senator)
